Shenzhen 518048 China Shenzhen Energy Environment Co., Ltd., Shenzhen 518048, China c School of Energy and Environment, Southeast University, Nanjing 210096, China School of Energy and Environment, Southeast University Nanjing 210096 China School of Energy and Environment, Southeast University, Nanjing 210096, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 Postal address: School of Electric Power, South China University of Technology, No. 381, Wushan Road, Tianhe District, Guangzhou, 510640, China The filamentous coke deposition limits the application of Ni/bio-char in the tar reforming process during biomass gasification. The addition of H2O and CO2 can improve tar conversion during the gasification process, while the effect of H2O and CO2 on filamentous coke deposition during non-oxygenates tar reforming process has not been extensively explored. To reduce the filamentous coke deposition by optimizing reforming agent, this work investigated the effect of reforming agent on filamentous coke deposition on Ni/bio-char catalyst during reforming of non-oxygenates tar. During CO2 reforming process, the accumulation of filamentous coke resulted in the decline of catalyst activity. In terms of steam reforming process, the promotion effect of steam atmosphere on mesopores of Ni/bio-char contributed to improving the conversion of non-oxygenates tar. The free radicals O* from the dissociation of H2O could oxidize the filamentous coke on Ni/bio-char, which resulted in the filamentous coke deposition (38%) in steam reforming lower than CO2 reforming (57%). Overall, the addition of steam in reforming agent contributed to improving non-oxygenates tar conversion and inhibiting filamentous coke formation during the reforming of non-oxygenates tar over Ni/bio-char. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords CO2 reforming Steam reforming Non-oxygenates tar Filamentous coke 1 Introduction Biomass gasification technology has been recognized as a potential method for utilization of biomass [1,2]. The syngas rich in CO and H2 can be applied to gas turbines for power generation. However, the formation of tar leads to a decrease in energy recovery efficiency and the clogging problem in downstream processes during biomass gasiﬁcation process [3–6]. Additionally, high CO2 content in gas products (10–30 vol%) reduces the heating value of raw syngas [7–9]. Besides, the syngas condensation produces a lot of contaminated water, which requires additional downstream treatment [10,11]. The conversions of tar, CO2 and H2O are essential for the large-scale application of biomass gasification. For further improving the syngas quality, reforming tar with CO2 or H2O have been explored to convert tar, CO2 and H2O into H2 and CO [12,13]. Tar reforming method was a promising technology to improve the quality of syngas. To further promote the conversion efficiency of tar, catalysts have been added to tar reforming process. Considering the high catalytic reactivity in tar conversion, the nickel-based catalyst is recognized as a promising catalyst in tar reforming process [14,15]. Researches have attempted to synthesize sustainable and cost-effective nickel-based catalysts. Bio-chars from hydrothermal carbonization of biomass are low toxic and inexpensive carbonaceous supports for nickel precursors. Besides, large amounts of functional groups on bio-char surfaces can improve active site dispersion by interacting with the nickel precursor [16,17]. Bio-char supported nickel-based catalysts (Ni/bio-char) have the potential to be applied in tar reforming process. However, the coke deposition limits the catalytic activity of Ni/bio-char [18,19]. Based on the morphology and structure, the filamentous coke and encapsulating coke are characterized as the main types of coke deposition during tar reforming process [20]. During tar reforming process, oxygenates lead to the formation of encapsulating coke, whereas the secondary reaction of CO, CH4 and light hydrocarbons result in the growth of the filamentous coke [21,22]. Due to the significant catalyst deactivation caused by encapsulating coke deposition, previous works [23–26] mainly concentrate on encapsulating coke deposition in oxygenates tar reforming process. However, the role of filamentous coke in the deactivation of Ni/bio-char catalysts in non-oxygenates tar reforming remains unclear. The type of coke deposition is related to the tar fraction, whereas the reforming agent affects the coke content. Water steam (H2O) and carbon dioxide (CO2) intrinsically formed from biomass gasification process can be employed as reforming agents in tar reforming process [27,28]. CO2 reforming of non-oxygenates tar produce higher content of CO than steam reforming of non-oxygenates tar. Large amounts of CO further aggravates the filamentous coke formation via Boudouard reaction [20]. As for steam reforming of tar, the H2O atmosphere can reduce the precursor of filamentous coke (CO) by accelerating the water-gas shift reaction (CO+H2O→H2 +CO2). Besides, a high H2O proportion in the steam reforming agent can reduce the coke amount via the gasification of coke precursors (C+H2O→CO+H2) [22]. Thus, adjusting the reforming agent can be recognized as a promising method to reduce filamentous coke deposition during the non-oxygenates tar reforming process. Due to the significant effect of encapsulating coke on catalyst deactivation, previous studies [24–26] mainly concentrate on the encapsulating coke during reforming of oxygenates tar, while the role of filamentous coke in the deactivation of Ni/bio-char catalysts during non-oxygenates tar reforming process remains unclear. In addition, although the effect of H2O and CO2 on tar conversion has been investigated in biomass gasification experiment [27,29,30], the influence of H2O and CO2 on filamentous coke deposited on Ni/bio-char during non-oxygenates tar reforming process has not been extensively explored. The optimization of reforming agent has the potential to inhibit filamentous coke accumulation. Thus, the effect of reforming agent on filamentous coke deposition during non-oxygenates tar reforming deserves to be investigated. In this work, CO2 and H2O were applied as reforming agents in non-oxygenates tar reforming process over Ni/Bio-char catalyst. The catalytic activities and coke deposition characteristics of Ni/Bio-char under different reforming agents were evaluated comparatively. The effect of H2O and CO2 on catalyst activity and filamentous coke deposition was discussed. Based on the analyses of non-oxygenates tar reforming experiment and catalyst characterization, the possible reaction mechanism of tar conversion and filamentous coke formation pathways under different reforming agent was discussed. Understanding the effect of H2O and CO2 on catalyst activity and filamentous coke deposition can provide a reference for optimizing the reforming agent, contributing to reduce the filamentous coke deposition and improving the catalyst activity of Ni/bio-char. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Raw materials In this work, nickel nitrate (analytical grade, Guangzhou Chemical Reagent Factory) was applied as the nickel precursor. Sweet potato residue recovered from starch processing plant [31] was employed to synthesize bio-char support for nickel precursors. 2.2 Catalysts preparation The detailed catalysts preparation procedure (Fig. S1) was reported in our previous study [32]. Briefly, the raw material is 5 g sweet potato residue and 100 mL ultrapure water during the synthesis of bio-char. As for the preparation of Ni/bio-char catalyst, the raw material is 5 g sweet potato residue and 100 mL nickel nitrate solutions (1.0 mol/L). The reaction temperature and residence time were set as 250 °C and 60 min. The autoclaves (Fig. S2) were cooled down after hydrothermal treatment. The solid product recovered from filtration was dried at 105 °C for 12 h and then calcined at 900 °C for 2 h in fixed-bed reactor. After fixed-bed reactor is cooled, bio-char and Ni/bio-char catalyst were obtained. 2.3 Non-oxygenates tar reforming experiment The model compounds of tar were commonly applied in tar reforming experiments [33,34]. The encapsulating coke was the main reason for catalyst deactivation during oxygenates tar reforming process [24,35], while the filamentous coke was the dominant coke deposition on Ni/bio-char during non-oxygenates tar reforming. This work used toluene as a model non-oxygenates tar compound to investigate the filamentous coke deposition on Ni/bio-char catalysts. The experimental schematic of tar reforming experiment was shown in Fig.S3. In terms of CO2 reforming experiment, the reforming experiment was carried out at 800 °C under Ar (75 mL/min) and CO2 (25 mL/min) atmospheres. Before each experiment, Ni/bio-char (100 mg) was loaded into the quartz tube and purged with Ar (75 mL/min) for 30 min. After the reactor was heated up to 800 °C, toluene was injected into the fixed-bed reactor at a flow rate of 1 mL/h. The compositions of gaseous products were characterized by a GC-FID/TCD (7890B, Agilent, U.S.A). In terms of steam reforming of toluene, the reforming agents were Ar and H2O at flow rates of 75 mL/min and 1.2 mL/min, respectively. Toluene was injected into the fixed-bed reactor at a flow rate of 1 mL/h. The following procedures were similar to the experiment of CO2 reforming of toluene. Under different atmospheres, the hydrogen conversion (XH) and carbon conversion (XC) were employed to reflect the toluene conversion rate in reforming process. As for the CO2 reforming of toluene, the XH and XC can be calculated based on the reaction equation (Eq. 1). (1) C7H8+7 CO2→14 CO+4 H2 (2) X H = M H 2 4 × M Toluene × 100 % (3) X C = M CO 14 × M Toluene × 100 % Similarly, in terms of steam reforming of toluene, the XH and XC were calculated based on the reaction equation (Eq. 4). (4) C7H8+7 H2O→7 CO+11 H2 (5) X H = M H 2 11 × M Toluene × 100 % (6) X C = M CO 7 × M Toluene × 100 % In Eq. 1 to Eq. 6, MCO, MH2 and MToluene refer to the molar mass of CO, the molar mass of H2 and toluene fed, respectively. The experimental yields of H2 and CO were calculated as follow: (7) Experimental - Y H 2 = V × C H 2 m Toluene (8) Experimental - Y CO = V × C CO m Toluene where CH2 (%), CCO (%) and V (mL) are the concentration of H2 and CO in gaseous products and the total volume of gaseous products, respectively. mToluene (g) refers to the mass of toluene fed. Not all the H2 and CO formed comes from toluene, but an important part of the CO formed in Eq. 1 comes from the reactant CO2, whereas part of the H2 formed comes from H2O in Eq. 4. In addition to the main reforming reaction (Eq. 1 and Eq. 4), some possible side reactions may occur during tar reforming experiment under different reforming agents [36]. (9) Water-gas shift reaction: H2O + CO→H2 + CO2, ∆H=−42 kJ/mol (10) Reverse Boudouard reaction: CO2+ C ↔2CO, ∆H=+173 kJ/mol (11) Cracking reaction: CnHm →nC + (m/2) H2 (12) Water-gas reaction: H2O + C↔H2 + CO, ∆H=+131 kJ/mol To explore the effect of side reactions on product selectivity, the theoretical yields of H2 and CO were calculated based on the stoichiometric number of reaction equations. In terms of steam reforming of toluene, the theoretical yields of H2 and CO were calculated as followed: (13) Theoretical - Y H 2 = 4 × Experimental - Y CO 14 (14) Theoretical - Y CO = 14 × Experimental - Y H 2 4 As for steam reforming of toluene, the theoretical yields of H2 and CO were calculated as followed: (15) Theoretical - Y H 2 = 11 × Experimental - Y CO 7 (16) Theoretical - Y CO = 7 × Experimental - Y H 2 11 2.4 Catalyst characterization The microstructures of bio-char and Ni/bio-char were characterized by a scan electron microscope (SEM, Merlin). The surface area was measured by an automatic surface area and porosity analyzer (ASAP 2020, Micromeritics, USA). Poly-crystal X-ray diffraction (X′pert3 Powder, PANalytical, Netherlands) was employed to determine the crystalline structures of Ni/bio-char catalyst. The content of coke deposited on spent Ni/bio-char catalysts was measured by temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) by a thermalgravimetric analyzer (TGA, METTLER TOLEDO). Detail information can be found in the Supplementary Material. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of bio-char and Ni/bio-char The microstructures and active site dispersed on surface are crucial to the catalyst activity. For measuring the microstructures of bio-char and Ni/bio-char, N2 adsorption and desorption experiment and SEM were used to characterize the surface area and morphologies. In addition, the metallic crystalline structures on Ni/bio-char catalyst were determined by XRD. As displayed in Fig. 1(a), cracks and pores exhibited on surface of bio-char due to the destruction of surface structure during hydrothermal treatment. In terms of Ni/bio-char catalysts (Fig. 1(b)), the interaction between nickel precursor and bio-char formed more particles on surface [37]. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms was shown in Fig. S4. The dispersion of nickel sites into the pore structure led to the surface area of Ni/bio-char catalysts (83.81 m2/g) lower than that of bio-char (196.89 m2/g). The XRD pattern in Fig. 2 showed the crystalline phases of Ni/bio-char catalyst. During hydrothermal treatment, the nickel precursor in the aqueous phase was converted into nickel oxide by thermal decomposition [38,39]. Then, after the calcination treatment, the metallic nickel particles were formed via the carbothermal reduction reaction between nickel oxide and bio-char. Thus, the diffraction peaks of metallic nickel (44.51°, 51.85°, and 76.37°) and nickel oxide (37.25°, 43.29°, 62.91, 75.40° and 79.37°) exhibited in the XRD pattern of Ni/bio-char catalyst. Previous works [40,41] reported that metallic nickel particles had high activity in tar conversion. The catalysts characterization suggested that the active nickel site was successfully loaded into bio-char during the catalyst synthesis process. Thus, Ni/bio-char has the potential to be applied in non-oxygenates tar reforming. 3.2 Effect of reforming agent on catalytic activity of Ni/bio-char For investigating the influence of reforming agent on the catalytic activity of Ni/bio-char, the hydrogen conversion and carbon conversion were employed to reflect the toluene conversion rate during CO2 reforming and steam reforming processes. The contents of H2 and CO were determined by a GC-FID/TCD. 3.2.1 CO2 reforming of non-oxygenates tar over Ni/bio-char During CO2 reforming experiment, the Boudouard reaction (2CO→C + CO2) was a side reaction that converted CO into filamentous coke. Consequently, as illustrated in Fig. 3(a), the carbon conversion was lower than the hydrogen conversion. As the reaction proceeded, the accumulation of filamentous coke on Ni/bio-char via the Boudouard reaction will result in the decline of catalyst activity. Consequently, as the reaction proceeded, the hydrogen conversion and carbon conversion decreased from 51% to 40% and 47–40%, respectively. To further investigate the product selectivity during the CO2 reforming process, the experimental yields of CO and H2 were measured and showed in Fig. 3(b). On the basis of the reaction equation of CO2 reforming of toluene (C7H8 +7CO2→4 H2 +14CO), 1 mol toluene theoretically produces 4 mol H2 and14 mol CO. Therefore, the experimental yield of CO (1365–1608 mL/g) was higher than the experimental yield of H2 (391–502 mL/g). Notably, previous researches [42,43] reported that the coke deposited on catalyst surface resulted in the deactivation of Ni-based catalyst. With the experiment proceeding, the filamentous coke accumulated on Ni/bio-char, resulting in the declining trends in the experimental yields of CO and H2. To explore the effect of side reactions on product selectivity, the theoretical yield of CO and the theoretical yield H2 were calculated. As shown in Fig. 3(c), at the beginning of the CO2 reforming experiment, the experimental CO yield was lower than the theoretical CO yield, which was ascribed to the conversion of CO into filamentous coke via the Boudouard reaction. With the experiment proceeding, the accumulation of filamentous coke inhibited the Boudouard reaction. Meanwhile, the CO2 atmosphere promoted the reverse water-gas shift reaction (CO2 +H2→H2O+CO) and reverse Boudouard reaction (CO2 +C→2CO), which further facilitated the formation of CO [10]. Thus, the experimental CO yield became higher than the theoretical CO yield. Due to promotion of the reverse water-gas shift reaction (CO2 +H2→H2O+CO) under the CO2 atmosphere, parts of the produced H2 were consumed, resulting in the lower experimental H2 yield than the theoretical H2 yield. 3.2.2 Steam reforming of tar over Ni/bio-char As shown in Fig. 4(a), similar to the CO2 reforming of toluene, the carbon conversion (31–43%) was lower than the hydrogen conversion (41–61%) during steam reforming of toluene over Ni/bio-char. The higher hydrogen conversion could be ascribed to the promotion of H2 production via the water-gas shift reaction (H2O+CO→H2 +CO2) under steam atmosphere. Conversely, the lower carbon conversion could be attributed to the consumption of CO via the water-gas shift reaction (H2O+CO→H2 +CO2) and the Boudouard reaction (2CO→C + CO2). Different from the CO2 reforming of toluene, the carbon conversion and hydrogen conversion increased as the steam reforming reaction proceeded. This may be caused by the different activation influences of H2O and CO2 on the pore structure of bio-char. The steam atmosphere accelerated the formation of mesopores, while CO2 activation can create more micropores on the Ni/bio-char surface [44]. Klinghoffer et al. [45] reported that the microporous structure limited the diffusion of macromolecules tar, whereas the macromolecules tar can be adsorbed by the mesopores on catalyst surface [46]. Therefore, the promotion of H2O to mesopores structure could be responsible for the increasing trends of carbon conversion and hydrogen conversion. For further investigating the product selectivity during the steam reforming process, the experimental yield of CO and the experimental yield of H2 were measured and displayed in Fig. 4(b). Based on the reaction equation of steam reforming of toluene (C7H8 +7 H2O→7CO+11 H2), 1 mol toluene theoretically produces 11 mol H2 and7 mol CO. Therefore, the H2 yield (1094–1629 mL/g) was higher than the CO yield (523–729 mL/g). The steam atmosphere promoted the production of H2 via the water-gas shift reaction (H2O+CO→H2 +CO2) and water-gas reaction (H2O + C→CO+H2), resulting in the theoretical yield of H2 higher than the experimental yield of H2(Fig. 4(c)). On the contrary, the consumption of CO via the water-gas shift reaction and the Boudouard reaction led to the lower experimental CO yield than theoretical CO yield. Overall, the accumulation of filamentous coke on Ni/bio-char resulted in the decrease in carbon conversion and hydrogen conversion in CO2 reforming process. The filamentous coke deposition limited the catalytic activity of Ni/bio-char in CO2 reforming of tar. In terms of steam reforming of toluene, the steam atmosphere can inhibit the filamentous coke formation and accelerated the production of CO and H2. 3.3 Effect of reforming agent on filamentous coke deposition During the tar reforming process, the accumulation of coke on Ni/bio-char could overlap the metallic nickel sites, resulting in a decline in catalyst activity. To investigate the effect of reforming agent on coke deposition, XRD, SEM and TPO were employed to further characterize the spent Ni/bio-chars from tar reforming experiments. The evolution of crystalline structures on spent Ni/bio-char catalysts was characterized by XRD. During the tar reforming experiment, the gaseous products (H2 and CO) and coke deposition formed via the Boudouard reaction could serve as a reductant for nickel oxide particles. Thus, as shown in Fig. 5(a) and Fig. 5(b), the metallic nickel diffraction peaks dominated in the XRD patterns of spent Ni/bio-char catalysts, while no diffraction peaks of nickel oxide exhibited in spent Ni/bio-char catalysts. Different from fresh Ni/bio-char, the spent Ni/bio-char had a new peak located at 26.38°, which was ascribed to the graphitic carbon in coke deposition. Based on XRD analysis, the coke deposition has been confirmed to be present on spent Ni/bio-char catalysts after the reforming of non-oxygenates tar under CO2 and H2O atmospheres. Besides, based on XRD patterns, the crystallite size of fresh catalyst and spent catalysts were calculated by the Scherrer equation (D=Kλ/(βcosθ)). The nickel crystallite sizes of spent catalyst from steam reforming (67.11 nm) and CO2 reforming (72.53 nm) were larger than that of fresh catalyst (62.45 nm). To further identify the type of coke deposition, SEM was used to measure the morphology and structure of spent Ni/bio-char. As shown in Fig. 6(a), some filaments structures occurred on spent Ni/bio-char catalyst after CO2 reforming experiment, but did not appear on fresh Ni/bio-char catalyst. The filaments structures on spent Ni/bio-char were filamentous coke. The comparison of morphology between fresh Ni/bio-char and spent Ni/bio-char suggested the filaments structure of coke deposition. In terms of steam reforming experiment, the water-gas reaction (H2O + C→CO+H2) could inhibit the filamentous coke formation under steam atmosphere. Thus, less filamentous coke displayed on spent Ni/bio-char after steam reforming experiment (Fig. 6(b)). According to the SEM images of spent Ni/bio-char catalysts, filamentous coke was the main coke deposition during reforming of non-oxygenates tar, rather than encapsulating coke. To further explore the effect of reforming agent on the content of filamentous coke deposition, temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) was employed to quantitatively determine the content of filamentous coke deposited on the spent Ni/bio-char catalysts. The filamentous coke has little effect on catalyst deactivation, unless high content of filamentous cokes accumulated on Ni/bio-char hinders the contact of the reactant with the nickel particles [20]. Considering the important influence of coke content on catalyst deactivation, TPO was employed to further measure the content of filamentous coke deposited on spent Ni/bio-char catalysts. According to the previous works on TPO analysis of spent catalysts [20,47], the weight loss peaks below 500 °C were assigned to the combustion of encapsulating coke, whereas the DTG peaks higher than 500 °C corresponded to the decomposition of filamentous coke. As shown in Fig. 7(b), the weight loss peaks in the DTG curves of spent Ni/bio-char catalysts were located at 600─700 °C, which was derived from the oxidation of filamentous coke. Besides, a weight increase occurred around 700 °C, which could be assigned to the oxidation of metallic nickel particle [48]. Based on the results of SEM and TPO, filamentous coke was the primary type of coke deposited on Ni/bio-char during the non-oxygenates tar reforming experiment. Consequently, the decline of catalyst activity during the non-oxygenates tar reforming process resulted from the accumulation of filamentous coke on Ni/bio-char. The content of filamentous coke deposited on Ni/bio-char can be calculated by TG curves (Fig. 7(a)). The weight loss of the spent Ni/bio-char from steam reforming experiment (38%) was lower than that from CO2 reforming experiment (57%), suggesting less filamentous coke formation during steam reforming process. Previous study [49] suggested that H2O and CO2 in reforming agent can moderate the coke formation via the water gas reaction (H2O + C→CO+H2) and the coke gasification reaction (CO2 + C ↔2CO). The activation energy of the water gas reaction (131 kJ/mol) was lower than that of the coke gasification reaction (173 kJ/mol) [36,50]. The conversion of coke needed less energy input under steam atmosphere, indicating that steam atmosphere had better facilitation on filamentous coke conversion than CO2 atmosphere. Thus, the content of filamentous coke deposition on Ni/bio-char from steam reforming process was lower than that from CO2 reforming process. Overall, the characterization of spent Ni/bio-char catalysts suggested that the accumulation of filamentous coke resulted in the decline of catalyst activity during non-oxygenates tar reforming process. Compared with CO2 reforming process, steam reforming process produced lower content of filamentous coke deposition. The steam atmosphere contributed better to oxidizing the filamentous coke deposited on Ni/bio-char, moderating the catalyst deactivation caused by the filamentous coke accumulation. 3.4 Reaction mechanism exploration Based on the tar reforming experiment and characterization of catalyst, the possible reaction mechanism of toluene conversion and filamentous coke formation pathways under different reforming agents were discussed. During CO2 reforming of tar, the active oxygen participated in the conversion of tar were mainly generated from the dissociation reaction of CO2 (CO2 + e* → CO + O+ e*) [10]. The active oxygen can further react with tar to form CO and H2. However, under CO2 atmosphere, the dissociation of CO2 produced large amounts of CO, promoting the formation of filamentous coke. The accumulation of filamentous coke deposition via the Boudouard reaction (2CO→C+CO2) and hydrocarbon cracking reaction (CnHx →nC + (x/2) H2) could result in a decrease of catalytic reactivity. In terms of steam reforming process, the adsorption and dissociation of H2O produced the H and OH radicals (H2O+ e* → H + OH+ e*). Then, the OH radical can further dissociate into H and O free radicals. Based on the free radical theory, the raw material is decomposed into activated tar fragments during the biomass gasification process [27]. The non-oxygenates tar fragments will be adsorbed by the nickel particles on Ni/bio-char surface and decomposed into light hydrocarbons. The secondary polymerization of light hydrocarbons precursor resulted in the formation of filamentous coke deposition [51]. The higher activity of H, O and OH free radicals can react with activated tar intermediates before secondary reaction, which can promote tar conversion and reduce the formation of filamentous coke deposition. Meanwhile, the steam atmosphere promoted the formation of mesopores in bio-char surface, which can promote catalyst activity by improving the adsorption of macromolecules on the catalyst surface [44]. Consequently, the conversion rate of tar over Ni/bio-char under H2O atmosphere is higher than that under CO2 atmosphere. During the reforming process of non-oxygenates tar, the filamentous coke deposition on Ni/bio-char accumulated as the reaction proceeded. The accumulation of filamentous coke could encapsulate nickel particles and block the pore structure on Ni/bio-char [52,53]. The filamentous coke deposition hindered the contact between reactants and nickel particles on Ni/bio-char, resulting in the decline of catalyst activity. Based on the characterization of spent Ni/bio-char, the reforming agents (H2O and CO2) displayed different effects on filamentous coke deposition. The schematic diagram for the growth of filamentous coke on Ni/bio-char catalyst was also proposed in Fig. 8. During CO2 reforming of non-oxygenates tar, the dissociation of CO2 produced large amounts of CO, which could aggravate the formation of filamentous coke deposition via the Boudouard reaction. As the filamentous coke accumulated, the heterogeneous reforming of tar on Ni/bio-char was inhibited, resulting in the decrease of tar conversion [54]. In terms of steam reforming of non-oxygenates tar, the active oxygen were generated from the dissociation of H2O (H2O+ e* → H + OH+ e* and OH + e*→H+O+ e*). The free radicals O* could oxidize the filamentous coke on Ni/bio-char, which contributed to inhibiting the accumulation of filamentous coke deposition. 4 Conclusions This work investigated the effect of reforming agent on filamentous coke deposition on Ni/bio-char catalyst during reforming of non-oxygenates tar. Due to the filamentous coke accumulation during CO2 reforming process, the hydrogen conversion and carbon conversion decreased from 51% to 40% and 47–40%, respectively. In terms of steam reforming process, the activation of Ni/bio-char by steam atmosphere improved the hydrogen conversion and carbon conversion from 41% to 61% and 31–43%, respectively. Besides, due to the oxidation effect of free radicals O* on filamentous coke, the content of filamentous coke deposited on Ni/bio-char during steam reforming process (0.62 g/g) was lower than that during CO2 reforming (1.32 g/g). Overall, compared with CO2 atmosphere, steam atmosphere has better inhibitory effect on filamentous coke formation during the reforming of non-oxygenates tar over Ni/bio-char. coredata.dc:description: The filamentous coke deposition limits the application of Ni/bio-char in the tar reforming process during biomass gasification. The addition of H2O and CO2 can improve tar conversion during the gasification process, while the effect of H2O and CO2 on filamentous coke deposition during non-oxygenates tar reforming process has not been extensively explored. To reduce the filamentous coke deposition by optimizing reforming agent, this work investigated the effect of reforming agent on filamentous coke deposition on Ni/bio-char catalyst during reforming of non-oxygenates tar. During CO2 reforming process, the accumulation of filamentous coke resulted in the decline of catalyst activity. In terms of steam reforming process, the promotion effect of steam atmosphere on mesopores of Ni/bio-char contributed to improving the conversion of non-oxygenates tar. The free radicals O* from the dissociation of H2O could oxidize the filamentous coke on Ni/bio-char, which resulted in the filamentous coke deposition (38%) in steam reforming lower than CO2 reforming (57%). Overall, the addition of steam in reforming agent contributed to improving non-oxygenates tar conversion and inhibiting filamentous coke formation during the reforming of non-oxygenates tar over Ni/bio-char.
coredata.dc:title: Role of reforming agent in filamentous coke deposition on Ni/bio-char catalyst during non-oxygenates tar reforming
